bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, July 10, 1880

div1.p: McPherson is sick and resting. Reed is studying for a medical exam.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Dorsey M. McPherson, July 10, 1880
div1.p:
Your last
letter came about a week
ago, but as I had already,
about a week before its
arrival, written to you, I have
been waiting for an answer
to that epistle before wri-
-ting again. It is equally ap-
-parent, however, that you
are awaiting an answer
to yours before writing but and
as you are an invalid
and deserving of a little
extra consideration on
my part, I will do the
honorable thing and not
postpone your letter any
longer. I assure you, my
dear “pills”, that I was
very sorry to hear of your
sickness- I had hoped that
you had escaped all your
many, and arduous cam-
paigns without injury to your limbs or
health; and I now sincerely
trust that your festive
lungs are quite “resolved”
and that the “wandering
cell” had returned to his
proper place- I think
Dr McCreery did the proper
thing when he recommen-
-ded that you be relieved
from further “field service”
and be allowed to rest awhile
on yours “cars-” you
have certainly had your
share of “roughing it”
since your arrival in
Arizona, and richly de-
serve a respite- Your
must pardon my pen-
manship, as it is intensely
hot and my hand is as “swea-
-ty” & sticky as so much
molasses- This is a dif-
-ferent kind of heat from
what you & I have been
accustomed to in Arizona,
and decidedly more pros-
-trating- My shirt is, at
present, “wringing wet”
and sticking to my skinny
old back like a cold
flannel cake to a grid-
-iron- Collars & cuffs
“wilt” as soon as put
on, and one's handkerchief
is kept busy all the while
“mopping” the sweat away
from one's “classic brow”!
And think of it, my boy
that in the midst of all this
heat & sweat & stink,
I must be pouring over
Eng. literature, History,
Anatomy and so forth!
What I don't know about
the rise and fall of the
Persian Empire and the
origin & insertion of
“gimbernat's ligament,”
isn't worth knowing-
Have reviewed “Osteology”,
“ligaments”, “Brain”, and a
part of “muscles”, “arteries”
& “veins-” I make my “break
-fast on “stewed” Physical
Geography every morning
For dinner, a “physiological”

regards to
Dr McC, the
K.O. & wife,
Capt. H. Mrs.
Hentig and
Harrison,
Lieut. Stanton,
Mr Lacey &
Staples - also
the Quarter-
Master's great
advocate
“Senor”
Kirchner;
